Apart from a few sententiae, the book consists of?¹ exempla or narrationes as distinguished both from fables and from moralised stories from natural history. Sometimes the writer adds a few words to point the moral—generally sufficiently obvious—of his tale, but he has little taste for allegory. His exempla are directed ‘ to the utility and edification of the people, announcing to them vices and virtues, punishment and glory‚'¹ and so far at any rate are in accordance with , the rule of St. F rancis, Ἀ
